description: From New Latin lyrātus, from lyra (“lyre”).

adjectives.description: lyrate (comparative more lyrate, superlative most lyrate)

examples: The passage of time could only enhance his tenderness for the creature he clasped, this adored creature, whose motion was now more supple, whose haunches had grown more lyrate, whose hair-ribbon he had undone.

entries.meaning: (botany, of leaves) Having a large terminal lobe and smaller rounded lobes toward its base.
examples: Basal leaves simple, lyrate or pinnatifid; cauline leaves 1- to 2-pinnatifid, pinnatisect or simple.

entries.meaning: A long curved feather found in a bird's tail.
